Hermite(Single, Single, Single, Single, Single)

Performs a Hermite spline interpolation.

Declaration
public static double Hermite(float value1, float tangent1, float value2, float tangent2, float amount)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Single value1

The startpoint of the curve.
System.Single tangent1

Initial tangent; the direction and speed to how the curve leaves the startpoint.
System.Single value2

The endpoint of the curve.
System.Single tangent2

End tangent; the direction and speed to how the curve leaves the endpoint.
System.Single amount

Weighting factor; between 0 and 1.
Returns
Type Description
System.Double

A double representing the result of the Hermite spline interpolation.
Remarks

This is a more verbose but readable version of MonoGame's Hermite. It returns a double rather than a float.

TestRandomCondition(Double)

Tests a random condition with one value.

Declaration
public static bool TestRandomCondition(double value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Double value

The value to test, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

true if the RNG value is less than a calculated percentage result, otherwise false.
| Improve this Doc View Source

TestRandomCondition(Double, Double)

Tests a random condition with two values. This is commonly used when calculating a total percentage of something happening. For example, this is used when testing whether a move will inflict a Status Effect on a BattleEntity.

Two values are multiplied by each other then divided by RandomConditionVal. A random value is then rolled; if it's less than the result, it returns true. This works for any non-negative values.

Declaration
public static bool TestRandomCondition(double value1, double value2)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Double value1

The first value to test with, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
System.Double value2

The second value to test with, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

true if the RNG value is less than a calculated percentage result, otherwise false.
| Improve this Doc View Source

TestRandomCondition(Int32)

Tests a random condition with one value. An int overload.

Declaration
public static bool TestRandomCondition(int value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Int32 value

The value to test, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

true if the RNG value is less than a calculated percentage result, otherwise false.
| Improve this Doc View Source

TestRandomCondition(Int32, Int32)

Tests a random condition with two values. An int overload. This is commonly used when calculating a total percentage of something happening. For example, this is used when testing whether a move will inflict a Status Effect on a BattleEntity.

Two values are multiplied by each other then divided by RandomConditionVal. A random value is then rolled; if it's less than the result, it returns true. This works for any non-negative values.

public static bool TestRandomCondition(int value1, int value2)
Parameters
Type Name Description

The first value to test with, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
System.Int32 value2

The second value to test with, representing a percentage with a number from 0 to 100+.
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

true if the RNG value is less than a calculated percentage result, otherwise false.

WeightedAverageInterpolation(Double, Double, Double)

Interpolates a value by weighted average. The closer the value gets to the target, the slower it moves.

Declaration
public static double WeightedAverageInterpolation(double curVal, double targetVal, double slowdownFactor)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Double curVal

The current value.
System.Double targetVal

The target value.
System.Double slowdownFactor

The slowdown factor. The higher this is, the slower curVal will approach targetVal.
Returns
Type Description
System.Double

A double representing the weighted average interpolation.
| Improve this Doc View Source
